awd_titl_txt: III: Medium: Collaborative Research: Deep Learning in Spectroscopic Domains
awd_abstract_narration:
Many problems in science today require the analysis of massive datasets. 
This project investigates the fundamental problem of extracting latent hidden regularities from high-dimensional scientific data sets, specifically from two different types of spectroscopic measurements -- three-dimensional hyperspectral imaging used in remote sensing of the Earth and other planets, and one-dimensional spectral signals arising from chemical analyses from laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy (LIBS), such as used currently by the Curiosity rover on Mars. The project is applying recent advances in deep learning, optimization, and machine learning to practical real-world scientific applications involving the analysis of materials from Earth and outer space, such as Mars, as well as the mapping of Martian and terrestrial surfaces through hyperspectral imagery. 

Deep learning uses multi-layer neural networks to construct a hierarchy of latent representations of high-dimensional datasets. This project designs novel architectures and algorithms for deep learning, and applies them to spectroscopic domains, such as LIBS and hyperspectral imaging. Three challenges from spectroscopic domains guide the research. First, in many applications such as the Curiosity rover on Mars, the number of available LIBS spectra are limited as it requires an active sensing operation followed by transmission of data by a robot situated millions of miles from Earth. A further challenge is that data from Mars is inherently unlabeled, and instrumental variations and terrain variations between Earth and Mars require solving a key transfer learning problem. For hyperspectral imaging, the project is extending work on deep learning applied to two-dimensional images to data that involves two spatial dimensions as well as the third spectral dimension, where images are recorded at multiple wavelengths. This project explores a variety of ways of designing new convolutional neural networks and other approaches that can effectively exploit the third spectral dimension.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE TRUSTEES OF MOUNT HOLYOKE COLLEGE

por.por_cntn:
This award has supported a systematic examination and quantification of the many factors that influence modeling of spectroscopic data. It has extensively investigated and documented best practices for the various steps of creating robust laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy (LIBS) quantitative models for geological and chemical applications, many of which are of interest to space exploration, mineral resource characterization, and Defense Department uses. Several different papers have tested machine learning algorithms and applied them to steps in processing and interpreting LIBS data. Our initial efforts focused on applying sophisticated machine learning techniques for calibration transfer between different instruments, such as those on Earth and Mars. A set of two papers examined how the background signal can be removed to improve interpretability of LIBS data. More recently, our studies have manipulated the order of preprocessing steps, the various techniques for normalization of spectral counts, matrix effects caused by interactions among chemical species ibn LIBS plasmas, size of calibration suite, univariate (one peak) vs. multivariate (using the entire spectrum) techniques, and cross-validation methods to refine the accuracy and precision of chemical measurements using this spectroscopic technique.

Over the course of this award, the broader impacts of this project include supporting 9 undergraduate student researchers, of whom 5 are currently in Ph.D. programs, 2 graduate students who now have Ph.Ds, and 2 post-doctoral researchers. We have published 11 papers in peer-reviewed journals, all of which contribute to the state of knowledge about applications of machine learning for the use of lasers in multiple uses. This work is foundational for a rapidly growing field at the intersection of machine learning and spectroscopy.


Last Modified: 05/24/2022
Modified by: Melinda D Dyar
